subject: Philosophy
title: Kant's Categorical Imperative
description: A 60-second lesson on Kant's Categorical Imperative.

hook.text: Kant said lying is always wrong â€” even if a murderer asks where your friend is hiding.

buildup.text: His categorical imperative demands: act only by rules you'd want everyone to follow.

discovery.text: If lying became universal, trust would collapse and lying itself would become pointless.

twist.text: The rigidity bothers many. Surely context matters? Kant insisted: duty is duty, no exceptions.

climax.text: Kantian ethics gave us the idea that some actions are wrong regardless of their consequences.

punchline.text: Act as if your choice became a law for everyone.

quiz.question: What does Kant's categorical imperative require?
options: Act only by rules you'd want everyone to follow
